channel.title: The New York Times Trends
channel.description: 用中文浏览纽约时报热门报道

item.title:
When families learned that a gunman had entered Robb Elementary School in Uvalde, Texas, a brutal wait began. Police on the scene did not stop the gunman for well over an hour.
The New York Times has put together an account of each of those 78 minutes. https://t.co/sj95rZc8T7

“Everything Everywhere All at Once” is multiverse galaxy-brain head trip, but it’s also a bittersweet domestic drama, a marital comedy and a story of immigrant striving, our critic writes. https://t.co/56j907MHTh

Paul Pelosi, the husband of House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, was charged with misdemeanor driving under the influence of alcohol in Napa County, Calif., on Saturday night.
Bail for Mr. Pelosi, 82, was set at $5,000. Speaker Pelosi was not with him. https://t.co/qWeuHh5tlV

Ukrainian soldiers, seeking to spread Russian forces thin, launched a counteroffensive on Sunday in Kherson, the key southern city that Moscow considered so securely under its thumb that it had introduced the ruble. https://t.co/hkjuaFtXwi

"Top Gun: Maverick" landed a triumphant opening weekend with estimated ticket sales of $151 million in North America. Analysts said it was a defining moment for the film industry’s box office recovery from the long pandemic slump. https://t.co/DbFzuQtZeP

It's time for the most striking sunsets of the year in New York City — Manhattanhenge is upon us.
You’ll get four chances to see it, starting on Sunday night. Here's what you need to know. https://t.co/bCdLfDO22J https://t.co/Z8JxaMECD3

Children’s learning loss in the pandemic isn’t just in reading and math. It’s also in social and emotional skills. In a New York Times survey of 362 school counselors across the U.S., they said students are behind in abilities to learn, cope and relate. https://t.co/CkyUNZ8q0e https://t.co/b3JnHMFdJv

President Biden on Sunday wiped away a tear while embracing survivors of the massacre at Robb Elementary School in Uvalde, Texas. It was his second such trip in nearly two weeks to mourn with families suffering from a mass shooting. https://t.co/tC7tiCDpjm https://t.co/UH4njxquim

President Volodymyr Zelensky visited frontline troops in northeastern Ukraine, marking a success for troops who pushed Russian forces back from the outskirts of the country’s second-largest city, after months of shelling that killed many civilians. https://t.co/LGfAdGzsur https://t.co/XhKgHgEEZ4

As polls opened on Sunday in Bogotá, Colombia’s capital, one name could be heard over and over in a working-class neighborhood: Gustavo Petro, the rebel-turned-politician who is making a bid to become the first leftist president in the nation's history. https://t.co/hePch9sL65

President Biden and First Lady Jill Biden visited a memorial at Robb Elementary School in Uvalde, Texas on Sunday. They stopped in front of life-size photos of the shooting victims, placing their hands on each photo and reading their names. https://t.co/56Pszn9Eqb https://t.co/Hz3bjFLU4g
Breaking News: The U.S. Justice Department said it would investigate the law enforcement response to the school shooting in Uvalde, Texas, that left 21 people dead. https://t.co/Dfh2Y5vb4q

President Biden will be attending Mass and meeting with grieving family members in Uvalde, Texas today.
Follow our updates: https://t.co/CVbta19JGM https://t.co/EEjwQPir3m

Just 12 days after mourning with families of victims of a mass shooting in Buffalo, President Biden will travel to Uvalde, Texas on Sunday to console a community suffering from yet another massacre of young children. https://t.co/lVLVoEKPCy

When families learned a gunman had entered an elementary school in Uvalde, Texas, a brutal wait began. Police did not stop him for over an hour.
This is an account of each of those 78 minutes — told by videos, witness statements and accounts of 911 calls. https://t.co/cCrEh6c7pu

Every mass shooting requires unique paths of mourning. The family of Celestine Chaney — one of the 10 people killed in the Buffalo supermarket attack — bid farewell to a mother, sister, grandparent and best friend. https://t.co/kWQOQWnjGv https://t.co/nMvn1OHUk4

Those close to Brittney Griner pursued a strategy of silence after the WNBA star's detention in Russia in February, hoping to avoid politicizing her case. Now they are amping up public pressure — with some of it aimed at President Biden. https://t.co/ocubpoBXBZ

There is a wealth of evidence that the 18-year-old Uvalde gunman teased his plans weeks before the attack. One of his co-workers at a Wendy’s said he frequently snapped at other employees, and that they took to calling him names including "school shooter." https://t.co/zDtAeMkDRP

A new law in Texas bans state agencies from working with a firm that "discriminates" against gun companies or individuals in the gun industry. As large companies grapple with how to respond to tragedies, laws like this one make it harder to take a stance. https://t.co/nAqN314AqN

The Texas school shooting has put a national spotlight on Daniel Defense and its aggressive, boundary-pushing style of weapons marketing. The company's sales have soared, in part because of successful targeting of young customers like the Uvalde gunman. https://t.co/XngD8spsOX

Vice President Kamala Harris spoke at the funeral services for Ruth Whitfield, the oldest victim in the Buffalo shooting, on Saturday, saying she believes "our nation is experiencing an epidemic of hate." https://t.co/JWrg5J1qvy https://t.co/mdOt7pg8au

There was no final miracle for Real Madrid in the Champions League final, no extraordinary encore. There was just an exact, painstaking plan, executed to perfection — one that ended with a 1-0 victory over Liverpool and a 14th European Cup. https://t.co/08pTB4xcMu https://t.co/3D7ToElVwz

In Opinion
"Congress is fundamentally unresponsive to the needs of its most vulnerable citizens and has been corrupted by powerful interest groups," writes the Times editorial board. https://t.co/ByfqZgdLzN

Two of the nation’s most prominent police organizations told Congress on Friday that they were willing to discuss gun policies in an effort to reduce gun deaths. It marked the first time that the organizations have commented on gun violence. https://t.co/WRAydnMWrc

In Opinion
"I think of child sacrifice as a modern phenomenon, a barbaric one that defines this country," @maureendowd writes. "We are sacrificing children, not only the ones who die, but also those who watch and those who fear the future." https://t.co/2TCuIsv4G7

A California woman who repeatedly punched a Southwest Airlines flight attendant last year, bloodying her face and chipping three of her teeth, was sentenced on Friday to 15 months in federal prison. A video of the attack was widely viewed on social media. https://t.co/Czbv1vNgS1

Donald Trump and Ted Cruz defended gun rights at the NRA convention on Friday with some misleading claims about the efficacy of gun restrictions, gun ownership trends and school shootings. Here's a fact check. https://t.co/waowiVIS0t

The Biden administration approved sending long-range multiple launch rocket systems to Ukraine, a significant transfer that could hugely aid Ukraine’s defense of its territory in the Donbas region, U.S. officials said on Friday. https://t.co/XeSK9DXkqS
One by one, attendees at the NRA convention said they were horrified by the Uvalde massacre. And one by one, they rejected any suggestion of gun control. https://t.co/rMixfvaIiV

“Every time I place my hand over my heart and remove my hat, I’m participating in a self-congratulatory glorification of the ONLY country where these mass shootings take place,” Gabe Kapler, the manager of the San Francisco Giants, wrote in a blog post. https://t.co/CrGddG71XR
After 23 days of testimony, lawyers for Johnny Depp and Amber Heard delivered their closing arguments on Friday. Now, the case is in the hands of seven jurors. https://t.co/fMkPd4xd2y

Instead of posting about their game on Thursday, the Yankees and the Rays highlighted facts about gun violence on social media. “There are things that are bigger than baseball,” said Jason Zillo, the Yankees’ vice president of communications. https://t.co/a4HaIhiXeP

Priscilla Garcia, a resident of Uvalde, Texas, was outside Robb Elementary School after the gunman opened fire. She said she stood close to police and listened to their radios: “I heard an officer ask, ‘Are you OK?’ And I heard a child say, ‘I was shot.’” https://t.co/tp6J8nhQoG

Students who were in the classroom with the gunman during the Uvalde shooting called 911 several times, including a lengthy call during which some shooting could be heard, according to the director of the Texas Department of Public Safety. https://t.co/EmngxtwQ5p https://t.co/l2mYMEicfk

An anonymous donor has provided $175,000 to cover funeral services for the victims of the Uvalde shooting, Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas said on Friday.
Follow live updates: https://t.co/QJtoCCMNof

Protesters gathered outside the NRA’s annual meeting in Houston on Friday, days after the shooting in Uvalde, Texas, left 19 children and two teachers dead. https://t.co/e8k1kBoAYI https://t.co/fmKlepbuNj

Two months ago, the Uvalde school district hosted an active-shooter training for officers, using instructional materials that say the priority for responding officers is to stop the killing by confronting the attacker. https://t.co/Hbo3cNp6v6

Sen. Ted Cruz has angrily dismissed any talk about gun safety measures and insisted he'll speak at the NRA’s annual meeting on Friday. Sen. John Cornyn has backed out of his speech and pledged to try to find some compromise with Democrats on new gun laws. https://t.co/EGF3rPJDW7
“I don’t want anybody else to go through this.” These were the victims in the Uvalde school shooting. https://t.co/Opqga074UA https://t.co/LvG85dY7Uj

Rep. Carolyn Maloney, a top Democratic lawmaker, has asked the largest U.S. gunmakers to disclose how much money they make from selling weapons used in some of the nation’s deadliest mass shootings like the massacre in Uvalde, Texas. https://t.co/X0E2TRlxcO

A 10-year-old girl who was injured in the shooting in Uvalde, Texas, was discharged from the hospital, officials said. A 66-year-old woman and a 10-year-old girl, both in serious condition, and a 9-year-old girl in good condition are still being treated. https://t.co/7JMfNXx9E9

In Opinion
“It will be impossible to do anything about guns in this country, at least at a national level, as long as Democrats depend on the cooperation of a party that holds in reserve the possibility of insurrection,” Michelle Goldberg writes. https://t.co/EojmfvY7Ix

New photos from The Uvalde Leader-News shared with The New York Times show that children escaped through the windows on Tuesday after a gunman opened fire in their school, killing 19 children and two teachers.
Updates on the Texas school shooting: https://t.co/zZTQarWpAZ https://t.co/DpSFlD72s1

Four House Republicans including Representative Kevin McCarthy, the minority leader, signaled on Thursday that they would not cooperate with subpoenas from the committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol. https://t.co/W99bnMsR6s
Breaking News: A federal judge dismissed Donald Trump’s lawsuit seeking to halt the New York attorney general’s civil investigation into his business practices. https://t.co/P3PkrCVLqb

Russian forces want to burn cities in Ukraine’s east “to ashes,” President Volodymyr Zelensky said. He accused Moscow of a genocide and criticized the world for not acting earlier to stem its aggression. https://t.co/UmYmV4RLgo
Breaking News: Border Patrol agents arrived far earlier than disclosed, but the Uvalde police initially kept them from entering the school, two officials said. https://t.co/n70TuFLqS5
Amber Heard took the stand on Thursday to address what she described as the persistent harassment and mockery of her abuse accusations against Johnny Depp, her ex-husband. https://t.co/JnTJ866LYc

Daniel Defense, the company that made the rifle the gunman used on Tuesday to kill 21 people inside an elementary school in Uvalde, Texas, received a $3.1 million loan from the federal government in April 2020 through the Paycheck Protection Program. https://t.co/jPXwdjsqDH

Ray Liotta's performance as Henry Hill in "Goodfellas" injected a note of tenderness that’s all the more effective for coming out of the mouth of a slick sociopath. But the producer didn’t want to cast him originally. https://t.co/SIvruI0KTH
